That's a great lead! Your grandmother's memory of trying on the vintage diamond necklace is a wonderful story, and it's possible that she may know something about the clocks as well. Since she's already shared a fond memory with you, she might be more willing to open up and share more information about the clocks.

When you ask your grandmother about the clocks, try to ask open-ended questions that encourage her to share her thoughts and memories. For example:

* "Grandma, do you remember anything about the clocks that Grandpa used to collect?"
* "Did Grandpa ever tell you stories about how he acquired any of the clocks?"
* "Do you know if any of the clocks have been passed down through the family, or were they all sold or given away?"
* "Did Grandpa have a favorite clock or one that held special meaning to him?"

By asking these kinds of questions, you're showing your grandmother that you're interested in her memories and experiences, and that you value her knowledge and insights. This can help her feel more comfortable sharing information with you, and you might be surprised at what she remembers!

Also, don't forget to ask your grandmother if she has any photos or documents related to the clocks. She might have some old family albums or scrapbooks that include pictures of the clocks, or she might have inherited some of Grandpa's papers or receipts related to the clocks. These kinds of materials can be incredibly valuable in helping you piece together the history of the clocks.

Remember to be patient and respectful when asking your grandmother about the clocks. She might not remember everything, and that's okay. The goal is to have a conversation and learn more about your family's history, not to interrogate her or pressure her into remembering things she can't recall. Good luck!
